ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned some essential techniques in microeconometrics. I especially enjoyed the applied component of this course. Getting our hands dirty with real data was a valuable learning experience.
Methods for causal effect identification: RCTs, RD, Panel data, Diff-in-Diff and so on
Essential concepts in applied econometrics that are highly relevant to my professional interests.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: mike does a good job of going through materials from first principles onward

This course helped me firmly grasp the strengths and weaknesses of some econometric approaches. In my opinion, this course could benefit from an extra problem set and more formal derivations for each of the techniques reviewed, as in 558.
The greatest strength is the Professor!

The class gave me the chance to apply the theoretical concepts from econometrics to actual research. One weakness is that the class material was largely deeply academic and theoretical to the extent to which I felt like the term paper portion was very disconnected from the class materials.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it's a great motivator to start your own research and try a mini econometrics paper
